text: my unpopular opinion is that working
with non-type languages non-compiled
languages can be a nightmare especially
as your code base grows extremely large
I will say shout out to the Pinterest
team I think they've done a fantastic
job of making our pythonic API easy to
work with easy to read great
documentation great testing however if I
still if I just want to go in and read
one bit of the code it's really hard to
understand exactly how it works because
I don't know
for lack of typing I don't know what's
going into this function unless things
are really well named which
at the scale becomes hard to enforce uh
becomes a little hard to test you really
need solid unit tests for it you know
everything down to like input parameter
validation which is something you don't
need in a type language and I think it
becomes really easy to like accidentally
introduce some bugs so I know for a fact
that one of my friends in the past who
worked at Pinterest introduced one bug
where they accidentally reused a
variable that was defined elsewhere
overwrote that variable's name because
this file was like 900 lines long and
python didn't throw up any flags for
using this variable like go would and it
essentially caused a not going to go to
about the issues but it caused an issue
with the content user users we're seeing
and that's something we didn't realize
till the change went out and was live
for a few days I mean it was restricted
to internal employees only but
essentially because it was something
that I know that go would have saved
saved us like three days of wasted time
essentially
